reviews.review_msg: Class is established to be curved from day one. Lectures cover both theory and code, but you need to investigate the code base on your own to get a high mark. Tom listened to the suggestions, so the project work load has been reduced and you can also work in pairs. It's hard to do compilers justice in the span of 3 months, so he did a great job.

Lots of work for the compiler project but mostly due to trying to understand the code and trial and error. Apparently project has been made easier than prev years. Prof spent lectures at start of the term going over how to do certain parts of the project which was helpful to get started. Pretty accessible outside class for help. Lectures were ok.

Course is no joke - 2 courses worth of workload packed into 1. And it's already been watered down by a LOT.
Project is not dreadfully difficult as myth suggests - just a lot of trial and error + having to understand the codebase = very time consuming. Prof is knowledgeable and always available. Lectures are meh. You will come out a better dev.

You won't learn much theories about compilers, but will totally strengthen your programming. So, if you don't "die" for programming, never think about this course. The worst thing is that he doesn't clarify how to do his assignments, you have to ask him by email or in office hours.

I did not have a problem with his teaching. It was straightforward and he taught you what you needed to know for the assignments and exams. Unfortunately, his TA for the semester was totally useless. The assignments were hefty though, so for this class, make sure you start right away, because you will be doing coding all-nighters anyways.

This is a hard course. Lots of time will be spent on the HW. Ranging from 10 to 30 hours per HW. Form groups to reduce workload or solo for better knowledge.

Each HW progressively gets more difficult. Start early. Not necessarily hard theoretically.

Anoop cares that everyone succeeds and is available for questions. Would recommend.

379 is tough but worth it. We built a custom compiler over 4 iterations (30hrs each) with a contest at the end. Anoop's grading criteria is clear, projects are group-based, lectures are recorded, quizzes are online, and he replies quickly to questions. Would highly recommend Anoop, it is very possible to do well in this class and learn a ton.
Great guy, very chill and approachable. Explains things in incredibly detailed fashion and gives solid examples. The homework for this course is pretty hard, so be prepared for that.

I found his 379 class extremely challenging. Exams are fair and he was quite lenient on the final but his homework is very hard. I only recommend this class if you are a very good programmer and understand abstract concepts very well. I easily spent over 50 hours on assignment 3.

Homework mark is mostly known before submission (self auto-grader). Homework starts out easy (HW0,1,2), but becomes more confusing (HW3,4). Final exam reasonable. Grades are split fairly between homework, midterm/final exam. There are few reviews here because Anoop is awesome. Recommended.

Great guy, course was a lot of work but it was arranged in a way that made it fairly easy if you put in the time. The use of git to deploy assignments and fix bugs was great. Provided a generous amount of reference material to learn from. Compilers aren't really his thing, but he didn't do a bad job at all here.

Anoop is one of the best at SFU. His course website is great with very clear pdfs of his slides. Assignments are very well organized. He provides a test framework which helps a lot in trying to solve them. Very personable guy with a good sense of humor.

Compilers are hard. But anoop does it in a way thats manageable. Assignments take time and you need to spend a lot of time on them. But talking to my friends who took it in Surrey I spent significant less time on the assignments and felt I learned the same material.
Super difficult class with very time consuming assignments. He is passionate yes.  Somewhat helpful but 99% time is done plugging away at the assignments.
He doesn't know how to explain things. He's comedian rather than a professor.

On one hand,he is a nice and funny person.on the other hand, he doesn't really teach you anything,or he doesn't know how to teach.Notes are confusing rather than enlightening.Instructi0ns for Assignments are vague, you have to guess what he expects you to do.That being said, he seems to be better than the other prof(Shermer) who teachs 379 tho
Writing a compiler is a fair bit of work so beware the assignments.  Was an interesting class with pretty good notes (although perhaps a little overemphasis on grammars --- his research focus)

Compiler Design is the area of research for Apala Guha. Therefore, this course was really interesting and exciting. The process of writing compiler step-by-step was the most complicated part of the course however it was really useful. Also, I like her video lectures since they were always accessible and very informed.

i cant speak for 354 but she was really good at teaching 379 the test were very clear and you would pass them if you watched her online lectures which explained everything the assignments were more on the difficult side but her grading criteria for them is nice so try your best on them and youll get a good mark. overall highly recomended for 379

Great teacher, just be sure to go to all the lectures. She sometimes gives questions during lecture for practice which you can answer using an app. I found that part to be helpful and engaging. If you are good with programming this may be a good choice for you. Assignments are worth around 40%, so make sure your program passes provided test cases.
ez gpa booster class when she gives you double extension

Covid sucks, but online lectures are worse. Dry content and reading off slides for the entire semester is brutal. Thank goodness for 3x speed(no joke) as Tom is a slow talker. Proj. Itr. were brutal for amount of time req. and minimal resources available. This class will be ur life for 4 whole months. Exams were decent, But are only 20% of grade :(

Tom is probably one of the most accessible profs outside of class, you can stop him in the hall if you have a question and he'll help you. You need to attend lectures in order to get notes and information about assignments. Biggest downside is there is too much work (around 40-50 hours a week). Wish he would go more in depth with the theory though.

Take this class with him if you want your life to ONLY revolve around this 1 course. If you want to take more than 1 course, or work a job, or have any life outside this course, DO NOT even think about it. Only for people who live and breathe code.
Except to be spending 40 hours a week on homework. Ridiculously hard and is sometimes unclear on the board. Do not take the course with him.

CMPT379 Compiler is not easy. Prof. Shermer is good at explaining theoretical concepts in lecture. But before exams, practice how to do NFADFA, productions, and optimizations by hand. Later assignments build on your own code of previous, so bad practice hurts yourself. If possible, try not to take 379 with other heavy programming or group course.

Intense, but highly rewarding assignments. Very enjoyable and I learned a lot. I highly recommend taking this class with Dr. Shermer. If you're not a strong coder, however, it might be best to take less than a full course load with this class.

Most rewarding and challenging course I've ever taken at SFU. Hours of intensive programming assignments, but you learn very valuable skills. Tom is an excellent prof and is always willing to help or go out of his way to make office hours for you. Do not take if you can't dedicate 30+ hours a week to assignments.

If you want to take a class where you don't really have to do much work, just study for the exams, take his.  Assignments are really easy and take almost no time to do.  Lectures follow the book, so skip if you want to.
Great porf....You learn a lot
No Comments
No Comments
